user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of ws_receive_frame:
```c
static unsigned char *
ws_receive_frame (unsigned char *frame, ssize_t *length, int *type)
{
  unsigned char masks[4];
  unsigned char mask;
  unsigned char *msg;
  unsigned char flength;
  unsigned char idx_first_mask;
  unsigned char idx_first_data;
  size_t data_length;
  int i;
  int j;

  msg = NULL;
  if (frame[0] == (WS_FIN | WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME))
  {
    *type = WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME;
    idx_first_mask = 2;
    mask = frame[1];
    flength = mask & 0x7F;
    if (flength == 126)
    {
      idx_first_mask = 4;
    }
    else if (flength == 127)
    {
      idx_first_mask = 10;
    }
    idx_first_data = (unsigned char) (idx_first_mask + 4);
    data_length = (size_t) *length - idx_first_data;
    masks[0] = frame[idx_first_mask + 0];
    masks[1] = frame[idx_first_mask + 1];
    masks[2] = frame[idx_first_mask + 2];
    masks[3] = frame[idx_first_mask + 3];
    msg = malloc (data_length + 1);
    if (NULL != msg)
    {
      for (i = idx_first_data, j = 0; i < *length; i++, j++)
      {
        msg[j] = frame[i] ^ masks[j % 4];
      }
      *length = (ssize_t) data_length;
      msg[j] = '\0';
    }
  }
  else if (frame[0] == (WS_FIN | WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME))
  {
    *type = WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME;
  }
  else
  {
    *type = frame[0] & 0x0F;
  }
  return msg;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function ws_receive_frame:
#define WS_FIN 128
...
#define WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME 1
...
#define WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME 8
...
static void *
run_usock (void *cls)
{
  struct WsData *ws = cls;
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh = ws->urh;
  unsigned char buf[2048];
  unsigned char *msg;
  char *text;
  ssize_t got;
  int type;
  int i;

  make_blocking (ws->sock);
  while (1)
  {
    got = recv (ws->sock, (void *) buf, sizeof (buf), 0);
    if (0 >= got)
    {
      break;
    }
    msg = ws_receive_frame (buf, &got, &type);
    if (NULL == msg)
    {
      break;
    }
    if (type == WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME)
    {
      ssize_t sent;
      int buf_size;
      buf_size = snprintf (NULL, 0, "User#%d: %s", (int) ws->sock, msg);
      if (0 < buf_size)
      {
        text = malloc ((size_t) buf_size + 1);
        if (NULL != text)
        {
          if (snprintf (text, (size_t) buf_size + 1,
                        "User#%d: %s", (int) ws->sock, msg) == buf_size)
            sent = ws_send_frame (ws->sock, text, (size_t) buf_size);
          else
            sent = -1;
          free (text);
        }
        else
          sent = -1;
      }
      else
        sent = -1;
      free (msg);
      if (-1 == sent)
      {
        break;
      }
    }
    else
    {
      if (type == WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME)
      {
        free (msg);
        break;
      }
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_lock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  for (i = 0; i < MAX_CLIENTS; i++)
  {
    if (CLIENT_SOCKS[i] == ws->sock)
    {
      CLIENT_SOCKS[i] = MHD_INVALID_SOCKET;
      break;
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_unlock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  free (ws);
  MHD_upgrade_action (urh, MHD_UPGRADE_ACTION_CLOSE);
  return NULL;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: All other controlling expressions in the supplied code depend on runtime values or loop indices and therefore are not invariant: - if (frame[0] == (WS_FIN | WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME)) and the subsequent else/else-if branches compare runtime byte values from the received frame. - if (flength == 126) / else if (flength == 127) use flength computed from frame[1]. - for (i = idx_first_data, j = 0; i < *length; i++, j++) uses the loop index i compared against *length (a runtime value) so the controlling expression is not invariant. - if (NULL != msg), if (0 >= got), if (type == WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME), and other ifs evaluate results of functions or data read at runtime. - for (i = 0; i < MAX_CLIENTS; i++) is variant because i is incremented each iteration. - Calls to pthread_mutex_lock, recv, malloc, snprintf, etc., produce runtime-dependent results used in conditions. There are no do-while loops present that would fall under the do-while exception. Therefore, aside from the single reported invariant controlling expression, no other controlling expressions appear to be invariant and require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3.
